sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Four species of Xylaria were collected from Guizhou and Hainan provinces in China . Morphological and phylogenetic analyses (based on β-tubulin, rpb 2 and α-actin genes) revealed two new species ( X. sylvatica sp. nov. and X. wuzhishanensis sp. nov. ) and two known species ( X. atrosphaerica and X. cubensis ). Xylaria sylvatica is distinguished from X. spinulosa by lacking long thorns on the stromatal surface, and larger ascospores (23–28.5 × 7–9.5 μm vs. 19–23 × 6.5–8.5 μm) with a sigmoid germ slit. Xylaria wuzhishanensis differs from X. schweinitzii by its semi-globular or irregularly globose stromata, from X. atrosphaerica by its larger ascospores (23–30.5 × 7–9 μm vs. 17–25 × 6–10 μm). Their descriptions and illustrations are provided.
Key words: 2 new taxa, Karst area, Saprobes, Taxonomy, Xylariales

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Xylaria Hill ex Schrank
is the largest genus of Xylariaceae , and X. hypoxylon (L.) Grev. was designated as the type species ( Greville 1824 ,
Peršoh et al . 2009
). Currently, there are more than 800 epithets listed in Index Fungorum (2022) (accession date 1.3.2022 ). Xylaria species
are widely distributed in tropical, subtropical and in temperate zones (
Rogers et al . 2005
,
Kirk et al . 2008
,
Lodge et al . 2008
,
Trierveiler-Pereira et al . 2009
, Ma et al . 2013,
Fournier et al . 2020
), and grow mainly on dead wood, but also on litter, fallen fruits, dead palm leaves, seeds and on ant nests (
Rogers et al . 2005
,
Hsien et al . 2010
). The prominent characteristics of this genus are variable stromata visible to the naked eye; unitunicate asci, 8-spored, with a J + apical ring and colored ascospores with a germ slit. The asexual morph is geniculosporium-like, with hyaline to light brown, smooth, branched conidiophores bearing hyaline, roughened or smooth-walled, ellipsoidal conidia (
Stadler et al . 2013
,
Maharachchikumbura et al . 2016
,
Daranagama et al . 2018
). Many Xylaria species
are pointed out to be host-specific (
Rogers et al . 1979
, 1992 , 2002 ,
Ju et al . 2018
), and the kind of host has become an important basis for the definition of some new species such as X. byttneriae G. Huang et al .
, X. bambusicola Y.M. Ju & J.D. Rogers
and X. liquidambaris J.D. Rogers et al .
(
Ju et al . 1999
,
Rogers et al . 2002
, Huang et al . 2014). However, colonization of Xylaria species
on hosts is still unresolved (
Lodge et al . 1995
). Whalley (1996) classified the species of Xylaria on the basis of morphometrical characters by giving priority to the length and position of germination slit of the ascospores. However, when molecular data is used for classification and identification of Xylaria (
Lee et al . 2000
,
Hsieh et al . 2005
, 2010,
Hashemi et al . 2015
,
Konta et al . 2020
), these results demonstrate that some morphological characters occurred many times in the evolution of Xylaria .
At present, asci and ascospores still as important classify traits for Xylaria , but, other morphological traits such as color, size and shape of stromata are limited taxonomic significance in determination (
Lee et al . 2002
,
Ju et al . 2012
,
Hande et al. 2013
,
Hashemi et al . 2014
,
Wendt et al . 2018
,
Fournier et al . 2020
).

South-Western China is rich in fungi (
Dai et al . 2009
, Dai 2012 , Gao & Yang 2016 ,
Cui et al . 2019
,
Wijayawardene et al . 2021
). A large number of Xylaria species
have been described or reported from these zones (
Zhu et al . 2011
, Ma et al . 2012, 2013, 2017,
Li et al . 2013
, 2017, Huang et al . 2014, 2015). To improve the knowledge about the taxa of Xylariales in southern and south-western regions of China , an investigation was conducted in Guizhou , Hainan provinces. Four species of Xylaria were encountered, of which two new Xylaria species
are introduced while two known species are also redescribed in here based on morpho-molecular analyses.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Collections, isolations and morphological studies

Xylaria specimens were collected in the forests from Guizhou and Hainan provinces in China . Specimens were deposited at the Herbarium of Guizhou Medical University (GMB) and the Herbarium of Kunming Institute of Botany (KUN), the colonies grown on potato dextrose agar (PDA) or oat agar (OA) were transferred to three 1.5 mL micro-centrifuge tubes filled with sterile water, and 10% glycerol, conserved at 4 ° C and –20 ° C respectively, which were deposited at Guizhou Medical University Culture Collection ( GMBC ). The methodology used for morphological characteristics examination was followed by
Stadler et al . (2004)
. Materials were mounted in water and Melzer’s iodine reagent for examination. The photographs of stromata were checked under Nikon SMZ 745 series stereomicroscope and photographed using a Canon 700D digital camera. Microscopic features were taken by using Nikon digital camera (Canon 700D) fitted to a light microscope (Nikon Ni). More than 30 ascospores and asci of each specimen were measured using the Tarosoft ® image framework (v. 0.9.0.7). All photomicrographs were processed using Adobe Photoshop CS6.
DNA extraction, polymerase chain reaction amplification (PCR) and sequencing

Total DNA from fresh fungal mycelia was extracted with the BIOMIGA fungal genomic DNA extraction kit (GD2416, BIOMIGA, USA ). The internal transcribed spacer (ITS) and three nuclear protein-coding loci, β-tubulin gene, α-actin gene and RNA polymerase II second largest subunit ( rpb 2) were sequenced. Primers and PCR protocols were followed as shown in Table 1 . Amplified PCR fragments were sequenced by Sangon Biotech (Shanghai) Co. The nucleotide sequences of ITS, β-tubulin, α-actin and rpb 2 regions were deposited at GenBank.

Phylogenetic analysis

All sequences used in this paper were selected from the previous literature (
Hsieh et al . 2005
, 2010, Ju & Hsieh 2007 ,
Ju et al . 2009
, 2012 , 2018 ,
Hashemi et al . 2015
,
Li et al . 2017
,
Wendt et al . 2018
,
Vu et al . 2019
,
Konta et al . 2020
) and are listed in Table 2 . Camillea obularia (ATCC 28093) was selected as the outgroup taxon. Three datasets (β-tubulin, rpb 2 and α-actin) were aligned with MAFFT v.7.110 ( Katoh & Standley 2013 ) and manually optimized on BioEdit v.5 respectively ( Hall 2006 ). All characters were treated equally. The alignment was manually adjusted to achieve the maximum alignment and to minimize gaps. Maximum likelihood (ML) analyses and Bayesian posterior probabilities (BYPP) were performed by using RAxML-HPC BlackBox (8.2.12) and MrBayes on XSEDE (3.2.7a) tools in the CIPRES Science Gateway platform, based on a combination of β-tubulin, rpb 2 and α-actin sequence data. Both of the two methods use the GTR+I+G model of evolution ( Nylander 2004 ). The Bootstrap supports of ML analyses were obtained by running 1,000 pseudo-replicates and BYPP using a simulation technique called Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) to approximate the posterior probabilities of trees. Six simultaneous Markov Chains were run for 2,000,000 generations and trees were sampled every 1,000 th generation. The phylogenetic tree was visualized in FIGTree v.1.4.0 (http://tree.bio.ed.ac.uk/software/Figtree/; Rambaut 2006 ) and edited using Adobe Photoshop CS6. The alignment and phylogenetic tree were deposited in TreeBASE ID 29567 (http://www.treebase.org/).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Molecular analysis

RAxML and BYPP phylogenetic study using three combined loci (β-tubulin, rpb 2 and α-actin) were conducted. The alignment consists of 88 taxa for representative strains of species in Xylariales , including outgroup taxa with 1897 characters, of which 75 characters were variable, 1005 characters were constant, 817 parsimony-informative characters.

The phylogenetic tree (
) shows that Xylaria is polyphyletic in Xylariaceae , which agrees with the previous studies (Hsieh et al . 2010,
Daranagama et al . 2018
,
Wendt et al . 2018
,
Konta et al . 2020
). In this study, Xylaria can be separated into twelve clades. Xylaria sylvatica formed a sister clade to X. haemorrhoidalis Berk. & Broome
and X. spinulosa Q.R. Li & J.C. Kang.
Xylaria wuzhishanensis formed a clade with X. schweinitzii Berk. & Curtis. Strain GMB
0077 gathered with X. atrosphaerica (Cooke & Massee) Callan & J.D. Rogers
(HAST 91111214) with high statistical support (100% ML, 1.00 BYPP,
), and GMB0075 gathered with X. cubensis (Mont.) Fr.
(HAST 515) with high statistical support (100% ML, 1.00 BYPP,
).

Saprobic on dead wood, forming on the host surface. Sexual morph : Stromata semiglobular or irregularly globose, pulvinate, 0.4‒1.8 mm high × 1.4‒3.2 mm broad ( x = 1.4 × 2.3 mm , n = 10), with flattened or slightly convex top. Exterior grey dark to black, roughened by fine cracks and ostioles; interior whithish to light grey. Perithecia0.3‒0.8 mm diam., completely immersed, sphaerical. Ostioles inconspicuous. Asci 182‒288 × 12.3‒20 μm ( x = 237 × 16.1 μm, n = 30), unitunicate, 8-spored, cylindrical, long-stipitate, apically rounded, with a J +, wedge-shaped apical ring, blue staining in Melzer’s reagent, 7–12 μm ( x = 10 μm, n = 30) high, 3.5–7 μm ( x = 5.4 μm, n = 30) wide. Ascospores 20.5–25.5 × 6.5–10 μm ( x = 22.7 × 7.8 μm, n = 30), brownish-black, unicellular, ellipsoid to inequilateral, with broadly rounded ends, smooth, with a sigmoid germ slit nearly half spore-length, lacking appendages and sheaths. Asexual morph : Undetermined.

Specimens examined : CHINA , Guizhou Province , Duyun City, Doupengshan Nature Reserve ( 26.223062°N , 107.22846°E ), elev. 1086 m , on dead wood of unidentified plant, June 2021 , Youpeng Wu, 2021DPS13 (GMB0077, KUN-HKAS 122633; living culture, GMBC 0077).

Culture characteristics : Colonies on OA reaching 4–5 mm diam. after 2 weeks at 25 ° C . White at first, with regular margins, becoming moderately radiating furrows spreading toward the edge, medium becoming black from central; reverse greyish black ring in the center, white marginal area. After 4 weeks, colonies on OA reaching 9 cm diam., white, velvety, appressed with entire margins; reverse dark black. No conidia were observed.

Ascospores 8–9.5 × 4–5 μm ( x = 8.5 × 4.5 μm, n = 30), brown to dark brown, unicellular, ellipsoid-inequilateral, with widely rounded ends, smooth, with a straight central germ slit along much less than sporelength, lacking appendages and sheaths. Asexual morph : Undetermined.

Specimens examined : CHINA , Hainan Province , Haikou City, Huoshankou Geological Park ( 19.554365°N , 110.13203°E ), elev. 152 m , on dead wood of unknown plant roots, November 2020 , Youpeng Wu and Lili Liu, 2020HSK4 (GMB0075, KUN-HKAS 122631; living culture GMBC 0075).

Culture characteristics : Colonies on OA reaching 4–5 mm diam. after 2 weeks at 25 ° C . White at first, with regular margins, then with a peripheral ring-shaped extension spreading toward the edge of the Petri dish; reverse milky white in the center, light white marginal area. After 4 weeks, colonies on OA reaching 9 cm , stromata arising from concentric zones, cylindrical, tapering upwards, flexuous, unbranched; reverse light grey, emerge black dots. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In this study, we introduced two new species ( viz ., X. sylvatica and X. wuzhishanensis ) and two known species of X. atrosphaerica and X. cubensis based on morphological and molecular data. The genus Xylaria was shown as a polyphyletic genus in previous studies (Hsieh et al . 2010,
Daranagama et al . 2018
,
Wendt et al . 2018
,
Konta et al . 2020
). Xylaria is divided into twelve subclades in our phylogenetic tree (
), without forming a single branch, and it was not clearly distinguished from relevant genera such as Amphirosellinia Y.M. Ju et al. , Astrocystis Berk. & Broome
, Collodiscula I. Hino & Katum.
, Entoleuca Syd.
, Kretzschmaria Fr.
, Rosellinia De Not.
, and Stilbohypoxylon Henn.

Phylogenetic analysis demonstrated that Xylaria is separated into twelve subclades (clade 1–12,
), each of which have relatively-uniform morphological characteristics. Clade 1 is represented by X. polymorpha and X. cubensis and taxa in this clade have cracked outer layer of stromata; wrinkled surface or thick carbonaceous layer immediately beneath stromatal, without wrinkled on the surface; ascospores mostly 8–35 μm long (Hsieh et al . 2010). Clade 2 of Xylaria displays the rough stromata surface; flattened to bulky stromata, with rounded fertile apex; ascospores mostly 4–6 μm long (Cruzu et al . 2015,
Koyani et al. 2016
,
Fournier et al . 2020
). Clade 3 of Xylaria is characteristized by the broadly rounded fertile apices, subsessile to shortly stipitate stromata, enlarged at base; ascospores mostly 8.5–12 μm long (
Ma et al. 2018
,
Fournier et al . 2020
). The species within clade 4 possess features of irregularly stromata with superficial, flat-topped to slightly convex; stromata surface dotted with ostioles; ascospores mostly 9–15 μm long (
Ju et al . 2012
,
Tapia et al . 2017
,
Fournier et al . 2018
). Clade 5 of Xylaria has long cylindrical, dichotomously branched or unbranched stromata, overlain with a dark brown tomentum on the surface; ascospores mostly 7.5–9 μm long (
Ju et al . 2018
). Clade 6 of Xylaria has gregarious, cylindrical to clavate or fusiform stromata with rough surface, coarsely cracked into thick polygonal scales; ascospores mostly 7–10 μm long ( Rogers 1983 , Cruzu et al . 2015,
Fournier et al . 2020
). Clade 7 of Xylaria owns the turbinate to peltate stromata that highly aggregated into crust, with surface smooth to rugulose to top; ascospores mostly 9–11 μm long (
Rogers et al . 1998
, Hsieh et al . 2010). The species within clade 8 shows similarities which include pointed apex on cylindrical stromata; striped, persisting peeling layer on stromatal surface; ascospores mostly 9–16 μm long (Hsieh et al . 2010,
Hashemi et al . 2014
,
Ma et al . 2018
,
Fournier et al . 2020
). Clade 9 of Xylaria displays subgolobose on narrow connective stromata which surface covered withish layer; ascospores mostly 24–30 μm long (
Rogers et al. 1987
). The species within clade 10 has common features: stromata with pointed apex, and longitudinal, long striped peeling layer; ascospores mostly 8–16 μm long (Hsieh et al . 2010, Cruzu et al . 2015,
Karun et al . 2015
,
Peršoh et al . 2017
,
Ju et al . 2018
). The species within clade 11 mainly grows on the fallen fruits or seeds, which have stromata branched or unbranched at the base, surface roughened with wrinkles; ascospores mostly 9–13 μm long ( Winter 1887 ,
Backus et al . 1953
, Hsieh et al . 2010,
Himani et al . 2020
). Clade 12 of Xylaria has long cylindrical to cylindric-clavate stromata, 1.5–4 cm long at fertile parts, brown vinaceous surface of stromata; ascospores mostly 5–7 μm (
Ju et al . 2007
, Ma et al . 2013). The result (
) showed that most of Xylaria species
owning high sequences similarities, have common traits incuding stromata and the dimension of ascospores. But, it doesn’t mean that those species with similar stromata have similar DNA sequences and could cluster obviously in a lineage. During our studies of Xylaria specimens, we found that some specimens with similar stromata features have very different DNA sequences, while some specimens with relatively large stromata differences have high DNA sequence similarity. Maybe these are some special cases. However, we still believe that adding more available evidences may be a good solution for the accurate identification of Xylaria species
, such as DNA sequences and chemical composition (
Yang et al. 2011
,
Sodngam et al . 2014
,
Huang et al . 2016
,
Cheng et al . 2019
).
